circle.title: Circle
circle.text: A circle is the set of all points in two dimensions, at a fixed distance (the radius) from a given point (the center).

compass.title: Compass
compass.text: A compass is a drawing tool used for creating circles or arcs. It consists of two arms – the needle on one end is placed in the center, while pencil on the other end traces out the curve.

similar.title: Similar
similar.text: Two geometric shapes are similar if they have the same shape but a different size. We can move, rotate, reflect and resize one shape to match up with the other one. Their corresponding angles are equal and their corresponding sides are in the same ratio.

translation.title: Translation
translation.text: A translation is a transformation that moves a figure in a specific direction, without changing its angle or shape.

dilation.title: Dilatation
dilation.text: Une dilatation est une transformation qui redimensionne une forme géométrique, en la rendant plus grande ou plus petite.

circle-circumference.title: Circumference of a Circle
circle-circumference.text: The circumference of a circle is the distance around its outside edge. A circle with radius r has circumference C=2πr.

circle-diameter.title: Diameter (circle)
circle-diameter.text: The diameter of a circle is the distance between two opposite points on its circumference, and passing through its center.

pi.title: Pi
pi.text: Pi, often written as the Greek letter π, is the ratio of the circumference and the diameter of a circle. It is a transcendental number, and its value is approximately 3.14159265…

circle-radius.title: Radius
circle-radius.text: The radius of a circle is the distance (or a line segment) between its center and any point on its circumference.

irrational-numbers.title: Irrational Numbers
irrational-numbers.text: Irrational numbers are numbers that cannot be expressed as fractions of integers (rational numbers). For example, 0.333333… = 13 is rational but π, 2 and e are all irrational. The decimal form of an irrational number does not stop or repeat.

iss.title: International Space Station
iss.text: The International Space Station (ISS) was launched in 1998 and orbits Earth at an altitude of approximately 400 km. It is the largest human-made body in low Earth orbit, and has been inhabited continuously since launch. It can be seen with the naked eye from Earth.

degrees.title: Degrés
degrees.text: Les degrés sont une unité de mesure des angles, indiquée par le symbole °. Une révolution complète est 360 °, un angle droit est 90 °, et ainsi de suite.

base-10.title: Base 10
base-10.text: The decimal system (or base 10) is the numbering system most commonly used around the world. Every digit in a number can have one of ten different values, from 0 to 9.

unit-circle.title: Unit Circle
unit-circle.text: A unit circle is a circle with radius 1.

radians.title: Radians
radians.text: Radians are a unit for measuring the size of angles. One complete revolution (360°) is 2π radians – the length of the circumference of a unit circle.

trigonometry.title: Trigonometry
trigonometry.text: Trigonometry is a branch of mathematics that studies the relationships between the sides and angles of triangles. It is primarily concerned with the trigonometric functions sine, cosine, tangent and their reciprocals.

calculus.title: Calculus
calculus.text: Calculus is the branch of mathematics dealing with limits, derivatives, integrals, and power series. Common problems include finding the slope of a curve, finding extrema, finding the rate of change of a function, and finding the area under a curve.

sin.title: Sine
sin.text: Sine is a trigonometric function written as sinθ. In a right angled triangle, it is the ratio of the opposite side and the hypotenuse.

cos.title: Cosinus
cos.text: Cosinus est une fonction trigonométrique écrite comme cosθ. Dans un triangle rectangle, c'est le rapport du côté adjacent et de l'hypoténuse.

cylinder.title: Cylindre
cylinder.text: Un cylindre est un solide tridimensionnel constitué de deux côtés circulaires, parallèles et congrus (les bases), reliés par une surface courbe. Vous pouvez également considérer un cylindre comme un «prisme circulaire».

cone.title: Cône
cone.text:
Un cône est un solide tridimensionnel qui a une base circulaire _ reliée à un seul point (appelé _sommet) par un côté incurvé. Vous pouvez également considérer un cône comme une «pyramide circulaire».

Un cône droit est un cône avec son sommet directement au-dessus du centre de sa base.

sphere.title: Sphere
sphere.text: A sphere is a three-dimensional solid consisting of all points that have the same distance from a given center. This distance is called the radius of the sphere.

prism.title: Prism
prism.text: A prism is a three-dimensional solid that has two congruent faces that are polygons (called the bases), whose corresponding vertices are joined by parallel segments. The remaining faces of a prism are all rectangles or parallelograms.

cavalieri.title: Cavalieri’s Principle
cavalieri.text:
Cavalieri’s Principle states that if two solids have the same height and the same cross-sectional area at every level, then they both have the same volume.

We can use this fact to derive that the volume of prisms and cylinders is the area of their cross-section multiplied by their height.

net.title: Nets of Polyhedra
net.text: The net of a polyhedron is what you get when you “unfold” its polygonal faces onto a flat surface.

pyramid.title: Pyramid
pyramid.text:
A pyramid is a polyhedron that has a polygon as base, and triangular faces around the outside, that taper to a vertex.

In a right regular pyramid, the base is a regular polygon and the vertex is directly above the center of the base.

pythagoras-theorem.title: Pythagoras’ theorem
pythagoras-theorem.text: Pythagoras’ Theorem states that in every right-angled triangle, a2+b2=c2, where c is the length of the hypotenuse and a and b are the lengths of the other two sides.

circle-sector.title: Circle Sector
circle-sector.text:
A sector of a circle is a part of its interior, bounded by two radii and an arc. Its area is proportional to the internal angle, as well as the length of the arc. This means that

ASectorACircle=ArcCircumference=θ2π

cylinder-volume.title: Volume d'un cylindre
cylinder-volume.text:
Le volume d'un cylindre est donné par l'équation

V=πr2h,

où r est le rayon de la base circulaire et h est la hauteur du cylindre (la distance perpendiculaire entre les deux bases).

cone-volume.title: Volume d'un cône
cone-volume.text:
Le volume d'un cône est donné par l'équation

V=13πr2h,

où r est le rayon de la base circulaire et h est la hauteur du cône (la distance perpendiculaire de la base au sommet).

ellipse.title: Ellipse
ellipse.text:
Une ellipse est une trajectoire courbe qui entoure deux points focaux. Tout point sur la circonférence de l'ellipse a la même somme de distances aux deux foyers.

Si les foyers sont très proches, l'ellipse ressemble presque à un cercle. À mesure qu'ils s'éloignent, l'ellipse devient plus allongée.

Les ellipses sont un type de section conique: une intersection d'un cône avec un plan.

parabola.title: Parabola
parabola.text: A parabola is the shape of the graph of a quadratic function like y=x2. It is symmetric, U-shaped and can point either upwards or downwards. It is also a conic section.

hyperbola.title: Hyperbola
hyperbola.text: A hyperbola is the shape of the graph of the function y=1x. It consists of two disjoint parts, both of which approach asymptotes. It is also a conic section.

conic-section.title: Section conique
conic-section.text:
Une section conique est une courbe créée comme l'intersection de la surface d'un cône avec un plan plat. Il existe quatre types différents de sections coniques, qui partagent de nombreuses propriétés:

  • Cercle

  • Ellipse

  • Parabole

  • Hyperbole

gravity.title: Gravity
gravity.text:
Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces of nature, and it pulls any two masses in the universe towards this other. Isaac Newton discovered that the force between two masses m1 and m2 is

F=Gm1m2r2,

where G is the gravitational constant and r is the distance between the masses.
